definition: Autosomal recessive deficiency or dysfunction of the platelet integrin GPIIb/IIIa (alphaIIb beta3), preventing fibrinogen-mediated platelet-to-platelet aggregation and stable plug formation. Platelet count is normal; bleeding time is prolonged.

images.alt: Glanzmann: impaired platelet aggregation via GPIIb/IIIa defect

why_it_matters: Prototypic congenital aggregation disorder. Differentiating it from adhesion defects and from von Willebrand disease is high yield.
how_youll_see_it: Recurrent epistaxis, gingival bleeding, menorrhagia, and postsurgical oozing.
Smear may show few or no platelet clumps.
Aggregation testing: absent response to ADP, epinephrine, collagen; normal response to ristocetin.
problem_solving: Desmopressin does not correct; use platelet transfusion for major bleeds or procedures.
Antifibrinolytics for mucosal bleeding; recombinant factor VIIa can be considered in refractory life-threatening hemorrhage.
Avoid aspirin and NSAIDs and GPIIb/IIIa antagonists.

differentials.hint: adhesion defect; giant platelets; abnormal ristocetin that does not correct
adhesion defect with normal platelet count; ristocetin corrects with normal plasma
isolated low platelets rather than qualitative dysfunction

tricks: Normal ristocetin response helps separate Glanzmann from vWD and Bernard-Soulier.
exam_appearance: Child with mucosal bleeding and no platelet clumping on smear; aggregation absent to ADP, epinephrine, and collagen but normal to ristocetin.
Young woman with heavy menses and normal platelet count; congenital aggregation defect suspected.
treatment: Local measures and antifibrinolytics for minor bleeds.
Platelet transfusion for severe bleeding or surgery; consider recombinant factor VIIa if refractory.
red_flags: Major hemorrhage needs rapid hemostatic support.
Recurrent transfusions risk alloimmunization; coordinate with hematology.
algorithm: Mucocutaneous bleeding with normal platelet count -> order aggregation studies.
Absent aggregation to physiologic agonists with normal ristocetin -> Glanzmann likely.

cases.stem: 8-year-old with recurrent epistaxis and normal platelet count.
cases.teaching: GPIIb/IIIa defect prevents fibrinogen-mediated platelet cross-linking.

cases.stem: Teen scheduled for tonsillectomy with known Glanzmann.
cases.answer: Use antifibrinolytic; have platelets available for intra/postoperative bleeding.
cases.teaching: Desmopressin will not correct an aggregation receptor defect.
